awd_titl_txt: Investigating novel functions of septate junction proteins during morphogenesis in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
The final shape of an animal is determined by developmental events that rely on morphogenetic (change in form) processes including cell shape changes and cell rearrangements. Many of the mechanisms that provide spatial and temporal control over morphogenesis are conserved in all animals, yet knowledge is still lacking on how these processes work. For example, the current understanding of mechanisms that allow mechanical forces to propagate through a tissue is inadequate to fully explain morphogenesis in many developmental events. Thus investigating these control mechanisms in a simple model organism such as the fruit fly (Drosophila melanogaster) provide understanding of basic developmental processes that are shared by all animals. The Ward lab has identified a number of proteins that appear to function together in several morphogenetic events during embryogenesis in the fly. This research focuses on the molecular functions of these proteins in generating and propagating mechanical forces through a tissue during embryogenesis. In addition to the scientific advancements that will result from this study, this project will increase the participation of first generation and underrepresented minority high school and college students in authentic scientific research. Specifically, the PI will develop a new program to engage high school students from Kansas City, KS in a summer-long research experience centered on using model system genetics to study development. The PI is also a mentor for several programs aimed at increasing the participation of underrepresented groups in the sciences at the University of Kansas, including teaching a course on developing skills to apply to graduate school in STEM disciplines.

Morphogenetic events are triggered and controlled by developmentally-regulated signaling pathways that lead to actomyosin dynamics in individual cells. These forces must then be propagated through the epithelium and maintained in order to elicit appropriate tissue-level morphological changes. Although much is known about actomyosin dynamics, less is known about the cellular mechanisms involved in force propagation through a tissue. In preliminary studies, the PI determined that a large collection of genes that encode core septate junction (SJ) components are required for embryonic morphogenetic events in the fly. The SJ is a large protein complex that functions as an occluding junction. Importantly, the requirement for these genes occurs prior to the formation of the occluding junction, indicating a novel function for these proteins in morphogenesis. The overall goal of this project is to provide mechanistic understanding of how SJ proteins facilitate morphogenetic processes during dorsal closure (DC), a well-studied developmental event that occurs midway through Drosophila embryogenesis. The following aims will be addressed: (1) to determine if SJ proteins regulate the assembly and dynamics of actomyosin complexes during DC, (2) to determine if SJ proteins are required for biomechanical or adhesive functions during DC, and (3) to determine if SJ proteins are required to maintain apical/basal polarity. Actomyosin dynamics will be examined by live imaging and on fixed tissues with antibodies that reveal activated myosin complexes, while biomechanical properties will be probed by laser microsurgery experiments.

por.por_cntn:
Tissue morphogenesis is a general feature of development in all organisms, and yet we still have much to learn about the various mechanisms that connect pattern formation to the dynamic mechanical events that alter tissue shapes and ultimately drive the overall body plan of these organisms. The fruit fly Drosophila melanogaster is an excellent model system to study mechanisms of tissue morphogenesis. Over the past two decades, scientists have made considerable progress in identifying signaling events that contribute to pattern formation and in understanding the cellular forces driven by actin cytoskeletal structures and myosin motor proteins. In contrast, we know much less about the biophysical properties of the epithelium itself, which may be emergent in nature and depend upon such things as viscosity, adhesion, and polarity. Our preliminary data suggested that a collection of proteins that make up epithelial occluding junctions along the lateral membrane (referred to as septate junctions (SJ) in invertebrates) are required for morphogenesis in several different developmental contexts. More than 30 proteins are required for the formation or maintenance of this junction, which functions to prevent molecules from passing between the apical (top) and basal (bottom) sides of the epithelium. Many of these proteins are highly conserved in all animal species. Importantly, our data suggested that these proteins function independently of their role in forming an occluding junction. The Intellectual Merit of this grant was to determine the morphogenetic functions of SJ proteins in two distinct developmental contexts in Drosophila. Specifically, we set out to define the function of several of the core SJ proteins in development by characterizing their role during the processes of dorsal closure (DC) during embryogenesis and egg elongation during oogenesis. DC occurs midway through embryogenesis and is a coordinated morphogenetic process that drive epidermal sheets on both sides of the embryo towards to dorsal (top) surface to enclose the embryo in epidermis. During oogenesis, the egg chamber consists of the oocyte (and associated nurse cells) covered by a follicular epithelium. The egg chamber is initially round, but gradually becomes oblong over about 3 days of development. The key findings from this project demonstrated that SJ proteins are not required for early events of DC but are needed late in DC for cell shape changes including cell flattening, and for maintenance of actin and myosin structures and cell adhesion. There does not appear to be a role for SJ proteins in tissue-level force generation or for viscoelastic properties of the epithelium. SJ proteins are also not required for early stages of egg chamber elongation in oogenesis but are necessary late in the process to maintain elongated egg shapes. We also identified defects in cell shape and cell flattening in SJ mutant egg chambers, demonstrating conserved functions at these two different developmental time points. Importantly, these results highlighted an important, but underappreciated, mechanism of cell flattening that is required for multiple distinct developmental processes in many organisms. Finally, we demonstrated a role for SJ proteins in the polarized secretion of cuticle proteins that make up the developing eggshell similar to what has been reported for the secretion of epidermal cuticle in the embryo. Together, these results suggested subtle defects in apical-basal polarity in SJ mutant tissues that we were able to document with quantitative microscopic analysis. We published a research manuscript on the role of SJ proteins during DC in Frontiers in Cell and Developmental Biology, a manuscript on the role of SJ proteins during oogenesis in G3, and a substantial review of the non-occluding functions of SJ proteins in the Journal of Developmental Biology. We are preparing a manuscript to describe the role of SJ proteins in cell flattening during embryogenesis and another with a more detailed functional study of SJ proteins in egg chamber development during oogenesis. We presented results of this project at numerous conferences and invited seminars including several Drosophila Research Conferences and Cell Polarity Signaling Gordon Research Conferences.

 

The Broader Impacts of this grant included increased participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research and science outreach to kindergarten through high school students, particularly in resource-poor Kansas City, Kansas. This grant directly supported the training of one postdoctoral fellow, 3 graduate students, 3 technicians, and 10 undergraduate students. Three of the undergraduate students are from underrepresented groups, one of whom went on to medical school and another into a Ph.D. program at Cornell University. Outreach from the project included science programs to middle and high school students in Wyandotte County, Kansas, including hosting more than 30 high school students in a week-long summer research camp at KU over two summers and recruiting 9 of these students to work in labs at the KU Medical Center. We also developed curriculum for underrepresented students at KU to discern their career path, apply to graduate school and hone their communication skills.
